summary: This document is an email chain from late November to early December 2019 between UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) officials and a redacted US prosecutor's office (likely SDNY). The FCA's Mark Steward urgently seeks to identify who is handling the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, specifically regarding his relationship with JP Morgan's private wealth division, in order to coordinate.

persons.name: Mark Steward
persons.role: Executive Director, Enforcement and Market Oversight at the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
persons.context: The primary UK FCA official initiating contact with US prosecutors to inquire about the Epstein investigation, specifically regarding JP Morgan. He coordinates call times with his team and the US side.

persons.name: Kate Tuckley
persons.role: FCA official (likely colleague of Mark Steward)
persons.context: An FCA staff member copied on the emails who assists in scheduling the urgent call with US prosecutors regarding the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Harry Caldecott
persons.role: Private Secretary to Mark Steward at the FCA
persons.context: Listed in the email signature as Mark Steward's private secretary, consistently copied on the correspondence chain.

persons.name: Kelly Eldred
persons.role: Personal Assistant to Mark Steward at the FCA
persons.context: Listed in the email signature as Mark Steward's personal assistant, consistently copied on the correspondence chain.

persons.name: Jeffery Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the subject of an active investigation by US prosecutors. The inquiry focuses on his world and his relationship with JP Morgan's private wealth division.

connections.description: Work together at the UK FCA, with Tuckley assisting Steward in scheduling an urgent call with US prosecutors.
Caldecott is identified as Steward's Private Secretary in the email signature.
Eldred is identified as Steward's Personal Assistant in the email signature.
Steward is reaching out to the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to coordinate on the Epstein investigation, specifically regarding JP Morgan.
The document states Epstein was a client of JP Morgan's private wealth division, which is a focus of the regulatory inquiry.

events.title: Initial FCA Inquiry on Epstein Investigation
events.description: Mark Steward of the UK FCA sends an urgent email to US prosecutors asking who is handling the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, specifically regarding JP Morgan.

events.title: Scheduled Call Attempt
events.description: An urgent call is attempted to be scheduled between FCA officials (Steward, Tuckley) and US prosecutors for 4:15 PM UK time, but is postponed due to the US Thanksgiving holiday.

events.title: Call Rescheduling Due to Voluminous Material
events.description: The call is rescheduled multiple times as the FCA has received 'voluminous' additional material related to the case, pushing the discussion to the following week.

locations: 12 Endeavour Square, Stratford, London, E20 1JN, United Kingdom (Financial Conduct Authority headquarters)
New York, USA (implied location of US Attorney's Office)
keyFacts: The UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) was actively seeking to coordinate with US prosecutors on the Jeffrey Epstein investigation in late 2019.
The FCA's specific interest was Epstein's relationship with JP Morgan, where he was a client of the private wealth division.
The US prosecutors confirmed they had an 'active investigation' into Epstein.
The FCA received 'voluminous' additional material related to the case, causing delays in scheduling a coordination call.
The primary US contact is redacted but is from the US Attorney's Office (likely SDNY), and they are described as running the unit that oversees the Epstein case.
